introduction.p:
Let's return to the simple geometric series
\sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n
where x is some real number. As we have seen (back in Example and Lemma), for |x| \lt 1 this series converges to a limit, that varies with x, while for |x|\geq 1 the series diverges. Consequently we can consider this series to be a function of x
f(x) &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n & \text{on the domain $|x| \lt 1$}.
Furthermore (also from Example and Lemma) we know what the function is.
f(x) &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n = \frac{1}{1-x}.
Hence we can consider the series \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n as a new way of representing the function \frac{1}{1-x} when |x| \lt 1. This series is an example of a power series.

So we should set as our goal for this section, the development of machinery to define and understand power series. This will allow us to answer questions
Recall that n!=1\times 2\times 3\times\cdots\times n is called n factorial. By convention 0!=1.
like
\text{Is }\ e^x &=\sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty\frac{x^n}{n!} \text{ ? }
Our starting point (now that we have equipped ourselves with basic ideas about series), is the definition of power series.

subsection.title: Definitions

statement.p:
A series of the form
A_0 +A_1(x-c) + A_2(x-c)^2 + A_3 (x-c)^3 + \cdots =\sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n(x-c)^n
is called a power series in (x-c) or a power series centered on c. The numbers A_n are called the coefficients of the power series.

One often considers power series centered on c=0 and then the series reduces to
A_0 +A_1 x + A_2 x^2 + A_3 x^3 + \cdots =\sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n x^n

subsection.p: For example \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n!} is the power series with c=0 and A_n=\frac{1}{n!}. Typically, as in that case, the coefficients A_n are given fixed numbers, but the x is to be thought of as a variable. Thus each power series is really a whole family of series a different series for each value of x.

We now know that a power series converges when x=c. We can now use our convergence tests to determine for what other values of x the series converges. Perhaps most straightforward is the ratio test. The n^{\rm th} term in the series \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n(x-c)^n is a_n=A_n(x-c)^n. To apply the ratio test we need to compute the limit
\lim_{n \to \infty}\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right| &=\lim_{n \to \infty} \left|\frac{A_{n+1}(x-c)^{n+1}}{A_n(x-c)^n}\right|
&=\lim_{n \to \infty} \left|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\right|\cdot |x-c|
&= |x-c| \cdot \lim_{n \to \infty} \left|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\right|.
When we do so there are several possible outcomes.
If the limit of ratios exists and is nonzero
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big| &= A \neq 0,
then the ratio test says that the series \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n(x-c)^n
converges when A \cdot |x-c| \lt 1, i.e. when |x-c| \lt \frac{1}{A}, and
diverges when A \cdot |x-c| \gt 1, i.e. when |x-c| \gt \frac{1}{A}.
Because of this, when the limit exists, the quantity
Radius of convergence
R&=\frac{1}{A} =\bigg[\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big|\bigg]^{-1}
is called the radius of convergence of the series
The use of the word radius might seem a little odd here, since we are really describing the interval in the real line where the series converges. However, when one starts to consider power series over complex numbers, the radius of convergence does describe a circle inside the complex plane and so radius is a more natural descriptor. .
If the limit of ratios exists and is zero
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big| &= 0
then \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big||x-c| =0 for every x and the ratio test tells us that the series \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n(x-c)^n converges for every number x. In this case we say that the series has an infinite radius of convergence.
If the limit of ratios diverges to +\infty
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big| &= +\infty
then \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big||x-c| =+\infty for every x\ne c. The ratio test then tells us that the series \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n(x-c)^n diverges for every number x\ne c. As we have seen above, when x=c, the series reduces to A_0+0+0+0+0+\cdots, which of course converges. In this case we say that the series has radius of convergence zero.
If \Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big| does not approach a limit as n\rightarrow\infty, then we learn nothing from the ratio test and we must use other tools to understand the convergence of the series.
All of these possibilities do happen. We give an example of each below. But first, the concept of radius of convergence is important enough to warrant a formal definition.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Let 0 \lt R \lt \infty. If \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n(x-c)^n converges for |x-c| \lt R, and diverges for |x-c| \gt R, then we say that the series has radius of convergence R.
If \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n(x-c)^n converges for every number x, we say that the series has an infinite radius of convergence.
If \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n(x-c)^n diverges for every x\ne c, we say that the series has radius of convergence zero.

example.title: Finite nonzero radius of convergence
Radius of convergence = +\infty
Radius of convergence = 0
example.p:
The series \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty n! x^n has A_n=n!. So
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big| &=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{(n+1)!}{n!} =\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} \frac {1\times 2\times 3\times 4\times\cdots\times n\times(n+1)} {1\times 2\times 3\times 4\times\cdots\times n}
&=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}(n+1)
&=+\infty
and \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty n! x^n has radius of convergence zero
Because of this, it might seem that such a series is fairly pointless. However there are all sorts of mathematical games that can be played with them without worrying about their convergence. Such formal power series can still impart useful information and the interested reader is invited to look up generating functions with their preferred search engine. . It converges only for x=0, where it takes the value 0!=1.

example.title: An awkward series to test
example.p:
Comparing the series
&\ 1&+&\ 2x&+&x^2&+&2x^3&+&x^4&+&2x^5&+\cdots \\
to
\sum_{n=1}^\infty A_nx^n=&A_0&+&A_1x&+&A_2x^2&+&A_3x^3&+&A_4x^4&+&A_5x^5&+\cdots
we see that
A_0&=1&\quad A_1&=2&\quad A_2&=1&\quad A_3&=2&\quad A_4&=1&\quad A_5&=2&\quad\cdots
so that
& & \frac{A_1}{A_0}&=2&\qquad \frac{A_2}{A_1}&=\frac{1}{2}&\qquad \frac{A_3}{A_2}&=2&\qquad \frac{A_4}{A_3}&=\frac{1}{2}&\qquad \frac{A_5}{A_4}&=2&\qquad\cdots
and \frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n} does not converge as n\rightarrow\infty. Since the limit of the ratios does not exist, we cannot tell anything from the ratio test. Nonetheless, we can still figure out for which x's our power series converges.
Because every coefficient A_n is either 1 or 2, the n^{\rm th} term in our series obeys
\big|A_nx^n\big|\le 2 |x|^n
and so is smaller than the n^{\rm th} term in the geometric series \sum_{n=0}^\infty 2|x|^n. This geometric series converges if |x| \lt 1. So, by the comparison test, our series converges for |x| \lt 1 too.
Since every A_n is at least one, the n^{\rm th} term in our series obeys
\big|A_nx^n\big|\ge |x|^n
If |x|\ge 1, this a_n=A_n x^n cannot converge to zero as n\rightarrow\infty, and our series diverges by the divergence test.
In conclusion, our series converges if and only if |x| \lt 1, and so has radius of convergence1.

example.title: A series from \pi
example.p:
Lets construct a series from the digits of \pi. Now to avoid dividing by zero, let us set
A_n &= 1 + \text{the $n^\mathrm{th}$ digit of $\pi$}
Since \pi = 3.141591\dots
A_0 = 4 \quad A_1 = 2 \quad A_2 = 5 \quad A_3 = 2 \quad A_4 = 6 \quad A_5 = 10 \quad A_6 = 2 \quad \cdots
Consequently every A_n is an integer between 1 and 10 and gives us the series
\sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n x^n = 4 + 2x + 5x^2 + 2x^3 + 6x^4 +10 x^5 + \cdots
The number \pi is irrational
We give a proof of this in the optional ยง at the end of this chapter.
and consequently the ratio \frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n} cannot have a limit as n\rightarrow\infty. If you do not understand why this is the case then don't worry too much about it
This is a little beyond the scope of the course. Roughly speaking, think about what would happen if the limit of the ratios did exist. If the limit were smaller than 1, then it would tell you that the terms of our series must be getting smaller and smaller and smaller which is impossible because they are all integers between 1 and 10. Similarly if the limit existed and were bigger than 1 then the terms of the series would have to get bigger and bigger and bigger also impossible. Hence if the ratio exists then it must be equal to 1 but in that case because the terms are integers, they would have to be all equal when n became big enough. But that means that the expansion of \pi would be eventually periodic something that only rational numbers do (a proof is given in the optional ยง at the end of this chapter). . As in the last example, the limit of the ratios does not exist and we cannot tell anything from the ratio test. But we can still figure out for which x's it converges.
Because every coefficient A_n is no bigger (in magnitude) than 10, the n^{\rm th} term in our series obeys
\big|A_nx^n\big|\le 10 |x|^n
and so is smaller than the n^{\rm th} term in the geometric series \sum_{n=0}^\infty 10|x|^n. This geometric series converges if |x| \lt 1. So, by the comparison test, our series converges for |x| \lt 1 too.
Since every A_n is at least one, the n^{\rm th} term in our series obeys
\big|A_nx^n\big|\ge |x|^n
If |x|\ge 1, this a_n=A_n x^n cannot converge to zero as n\rightarrow\infty, and our series diverges by the divergence test.
In conclusion, our series converges if and only if |x| \lt 1, and so has radius of convergence1.

subsection.p: Though we won't prove it, it is true that every power series has a radius of convergence, whether or not the limit \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big| exists.

statement.p:
Let \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty A_n (x-c)^n be a power series. Then one of the following alternatives must hold.
The power series converges for every number x. In this case we say that the radius of convergence is \infty.
There is a number 0 \lt R \lt \infty such that the series converges for |x-c| \lt R and diverges for |x-c| \gt R. Then R is called the radius of convergence.
The series converges for x=c and diverges for all x\ne c. In this case, we say that the radius of convergence is 0.

Consider the power series
\sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n (x-c)^n.
The set of real x-values for which it converges is called the interval of convergence of the series.

subsection.p:
Suppose that the power series \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty A_n (x-c)^n has radius of convergence R. Then from Theorem , we have that
if R=\infty, then its interval of convergence is -\infty \lt x \lt \infty, which is also denoted (-\infty,\infty), and
if R=0, then its interval of convergence is just the point x=c, and
if 0 \lt R \lt \infty, then we know that the series converges for any x which obeys
|x-c| \lt R\quad&\text{or equivalently}\quad -R \lt x-c \lt R
&\text{or equivalently}\quad c-R \lt x \lt c+R
But we do not (yet) know whether or not the series converges at the two end points of that interval. We do know, however, that its interval of convergence must be one of
c-R \lt x \lt c+R, which is also denoted (c-R\,,\,c+R), or
c-R\le x \lt c+R, which is also denoted [c-R\,,\,c+R), or
c-R \lt x\le c+R, which is also denoted (c-R\,,\,c+R], or
c-R\le x \le c+R, which is also denoted [c-R\,,\,c+R].
To reiterate while the radius convergence, R with 0 \lt R \lt \infty, tells us that the series converges for |x-c| \lt R and diverges for |x-c| \gt R, it does not (by itself) tell us whether or not the series converges when |x-c|=R, i.e. when x=c\pm R. The following example shows that all four possibilities can occur.

example.title: The series \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n^p}
example.p:
Let p be any real number and consider the series \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n^p}. This series has A_n= \frac{1}{n^p}. Since
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big|\frac{A_{n+1}}{A_n}\Big| =\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{n^p}{{(n+1)}^p} =\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{{(1+\frac{1}{n})}^p} =1
the series has radius of convergence 1. So it certainly converges for |x| \lt 1 and diverges for |x| \gt 1. That just leaves x=\pm 1.
When x=1, the series reduces to \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{n^p}. We know, from Example , that this series converges if and only if p \gt 1.
When x=-1, the series reduces to \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{n^p}. By the alternating series test, Theorem , this series converges whenever p \gt 0 (so that \frac{1}{n^p} tends to zero as n tends to infinity). When p\le 0 (so that \frac{1}{n^p} does not tend to zero as n tends to infinity), it diverges by the divergence test, Theorem .
So
The power series \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n (i.e. p=0) has interval of convergence -1 \lt x \lt 1.
The power series \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n} (i.e. p=1) has interval of convergence -1\le x \lt 1.
The power series \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{n}x^n (i.e. p=1) has interval of convergence -1 \lt x\le 1.
The power series \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n^2} (i.e. p=2) has interval of convergence -1\le x\le 1.

example.title: Playing with intervals of convergence
example.p: We are told that a certain power series with centre c=3, converges at x=4 and diverges at x=1. What else can we say about the convergence or divergence of the series for other values of x?

We are told that the series is centred at 3, so its terms are all powers of (x-3) and it is of the form
\sum_{n \geq 0} A_n (x-3)^n.
A good way to summarise the convergence data we are given is with a figure like the one below. Green dots mark the values of x where the series is known to converge. (Recall that every power series converges at its centre.) The red dot marks the value of x where the series is known to diverge. The bull's eye marks the centre.
Can we say more about the convergence and/or divergence of the series for other values of x? Yes!

Let us think about the radius of convergence, R, of the series. We know that it must exist and the information we have been given allows us to bound R. Recall that
the series converges at x provided that |x-3| \lt R and
the series diverges at x if |x-3| \gt R.
We have been told that
the series converges when x=4, which tells us that
x=4 cannot obey |x-3| \gt R so
x=4 must obey |x-3|\le R, i.e. |4-3|\le R, i.e. R\ge 1
the series diverges when x=1 so we also know that
x=1 cannot obey |x-3| \lt R so
x=1 must obey |x-3|\ge R, i.e. |1-3|\ge R, i.e. R\le 2
We still don't know R exactly. But we do know that 1\le R\le 2. Consequently,
since 1 is the smallest that R could be, the series certainly converges at x if |x-3| \lt 1, i.e. if 2 \lt x \lt 4 and
since 2 is the largest that R could be, the series certainly diverges at x if |x-3| \gt 2, i.e. if x \gt 5 or if x \lt 1.
The following figure provides a resume of all of this convergence data there is convergence at green x's and divergence at red x's.
Notice that from the data given we cannot say anything about the convergence or divergence of the series on the intervals (1,2] and (4,5].

subsection.title: Working With Power Series
subsection.p: Just as we have done previously with limits, differentiation and integration, we can construct power series representations of more complicated functions by using those of simpler functions. Here is a theorem that helps us to do so.

statement.p: In particular the radius of convergence of each of the six power series on the right hand sides is at least R. In fact, if R is the radius of convergence of \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty A_n (x-c)^n, then R is also the radius of convergence of all of the above right hand sides, with the possible exceptions of \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty [A_n+B_n]\, (x-c)^n and \sum\limits_{n=0}^\infty KA_n\, (x-c)^n when K=0.

example.title: More on the last part of Theorem
example.p:
The last statement of Theorem might seem a little odd, but consider the following two power series centred at 0:
\sum_{n=0}^\infty 2^n x^n & \text{ and } \sum_{n=0}^\infty (1-2^n) x^n.
The ratio test tells us that they both have radius of convergence R=\frac{1}{2}. However their sum is
\sum_{n=0}^\infty 2^n x^n + \sum_{n=0}^\infty (1-2^n) x^n &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n
which has the larger radius of convergence 1.

A more extreme example of the same phenomenon is supplied by the two series
\sum_{n=0}^\infty 2^n x^n & \text{ and } \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-2^n) x^n.
They are both geometric series with radius of convergence R=\frac{1}{2}. But their sum is
\sum_{n=0}^\infty 2^n x^n + \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-2^n) x^n &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty (0)x^n
which has radius of convergence +\infty.

subsection.p:
We'll now use this theorem to build power series representations for a bunch of functions out of the one simple power series representation that we know the geometric series
\frac{1}{1-x} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n\qquad \text{for all $|x| \lt 1$}

subsection.p: In the previous two examples, to construct a new series from an existing series, we replaced x by a simple function. The following theorem gives us some more (but certainly not all) commonly used substitutions.

statement.p:
Assume that the function f(x) is given by the power series
f(x) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n x^n
for all x in the interval I. Also let K and k be real constants. Then
f\big(Kx^k\big) &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_nK^n\, x^{kn}
whenever Kx^k is in I. In particular, if \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_n x^n has radius of convergence R, K is nonzero and k is a natural number, then \sum_{n=0}^\infty A_nK^n\, x^{kn} has radius of convergence \root{k}\of{R/|K|}.

example.p: Find a power series representation for \frac{1}{(1-x)^2}.

Without much more work we can determine the interval of convergence by testing at x=\pm 1. When x=\pm 1 the terms of the series do not go to zero as n \to \infty and so, by the divergence test, the series does not converge there. Hence the interval of convergence for the series is -1 \lt x \lt 1.

subsection.p:
Notice that, in this last example, we differentiated a known series to get to our answer. As per Theorem, the radius of convergence didn't change. In addition, in this particular example, the interval of convergence didn't change. This is not always the case. Differentiation of some series causes the interval of convergence to shrink. In particular the differentiated series may no longer be convergent at the end points of the interval
Consider the power series \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n}. We know that its interval of convergence is -1 \leq x \lt 1. (Indeed see the next example.) When we differentiate the series we get the geometric series \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n which has interval of convergence -1 \lt x \lt 1. . Similarly, when we integrate a power series the radius of convergence is unchanged, but the interval of convergence may expand to include one or both ends, as illustrated by the next example.
